terms.definition: Computer-Aided Design - software used to create precise 2D and 3D technical drawings and models for engineering and manufacturing purposes
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides searchable access to technical knowledge and solutions
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted online and accessed through web browsers
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and maintain change history
A cloud-based system that enables teams to create, manage, organize, and collaborate on technical documents and knowledge resources
A feature that allows multiple people to simultaneously edit and collaborate on the same document in real-time
Groups of people with different functional expertise working together toward a common goal, such as engineers, designers, and production staff
Detailed instructional documents that provide step-by-step guidance for operating, maintaining, or troubleshooting equipment and systems
Documentation that demonstrates adherence to industry regulations, safety standards, and quality requirements
Automatically generated condensed versions of lengthy documents created using artificial intelligence to highlight key information
A chronological record of all changes, edits, and access to documents that provides accountability and traceability
Feedback and discussion notes that are embedded directly within a document at specific locations rather than in separate communication channels
Pre-formatted document structures that ensure consistency and compliance with standards across all documentation
A single, unified location where all documents and information are stored and managed, providing easy access to team members
Immediate synchronization of changes across all users and systems as modifications are made to documents or data
